ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
TALKS WITH MALAYSIA
(Negotiation on package of issues)


    1. Dr Ong Chit Chung asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, with reference

Column: 588

to the meetings held in Kuala Lumpur on 1st and 2nd July 2002, if he will inform the House of the state of progress of talks with Malaysia on the outstanding issues as well as comment on the recent remarks by the Malaysian Foreign Minister on their proposed price of water under the 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements.

    The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I welcome this opportunity to inform the House of the state of play in our negotiations with Malaysia after our last meeting in Putrajaya on 1st and 2nd July 2002. It has been a long road. Our discussions on 1st and 2nd July were part of a process that has been on-going at various levels since 1998. There have also been several exchanges of letters setting out different proposals.

    I shall not recap every last twist-and-turn of this process. There is still some way to go before we reach agreement. So neither is it appropriate for me to reveal every last detail of what is still being negotiated. But there have been many media statements about the negotiations which may have resulted in some public confusion. I will therefore try to be as clear as possible where we are at this point of time. I will also set out clearly Singapore's consistent approach towards the negotiations.

    Our negotiations in Putrajaya in July were preceded by an exchange of letters at the highest level. On 4th March 2002, Prime Minister Mahathir wrote to us setting out certain proposals. These proposals were completely new and different from what had been discussed during the meetings between Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew and Dr Mahathir in September 2001. On 11th April 2002, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong replied, setting out our various counter-proposals. This exchange of letters established the basic framework for our discussions recently in July.

    Our discussions are on a package of issues. Prime Minister Mahathir's letter of 4th March dealt with water, railway, a proposed bridge to replace the Causeway, CIQ, CPF and airspace; Prime Minister

Column: 589

Goh's reply of 11th April dealt with the same issues. By establishing the basic framework for our negotiations, this exchange of letters also defined the package. By a package, we mean that nothing is resolved until everything is resolved and that there can be trade-offs between the issues to satisfy the interests of both parties.

    Let me now comment on the specific issues which were discussed during our meetings on 1st and 2nd July.

Water

    There are three aspects to the water issue:

    First, the observance of the existing Water Agreements of 1961 and 1962.

    Second, the price of water supplied under possible new agreements after the expiry of the 1961 and 1962 Agreements in 2011 and 2061 respectively.

    Third, Malaysia's proposal to invoke the price review clauses of the 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements.

    I will deal with each of these aspects in turn. Existing Agreements

    Singapore's consistent and firm position is, and remains, that the 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements are valid and legally binding agreements, enshrined under the

1965    Separation Agreement, and must be honoured. The terms of the 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements cannot be unilaterally changed. This is a fundamental and non-negotiable point. Whether or not we agree on the supply of water after the expiry of these two agreements is a completely separate matter.

    In a formal statement on 1st July, the Malaysian side assured us that Malaysia would "honour the 1961 and

1962    Water Agreements until their expiry in 2011 and 2061 respectively". Malaysia was also

Column: 590

clear that it does not propose to amend the terms of the 1961 and 1962 Agreements. We welcome these assurances.

New Agreements

    On 5th April 2002, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong explained to this House why Singapore wants to reduce our dependence on Malaysian water. Prime Minister Goh said that it was not healthy for our countries to be always locked in disputes over water and to allow this one issue to sour bilateral relations and prevent us from cooperating in strategic areas of mutual benefit. By next year, our Bedok and Kranji NEWater plants will be in operation. By 2011, two more NEWater plants in Seletar and Ulu Pandan will be ready.

    We can allow the 1961 Agreement to lapse in 2011. It is within our means to produce sufficient water to replace the water from the 1961 Agreement. However, we are still prepared to buy some water from Malaysia after the expiry of the 1961 Agreement. But the price must be right.

    After 2061, when the 1962 Agreement expires, it only makes economic sense for us to continue to buy additional water from Malaysia, if the cost of that water is less than the water we can produce ourselves. The price must be competitive in relation to the cost of our alternative sources of water.

    At the recent talks, we have briefed the Malaysians about our plans to develop alternative sources of water by increasing our catchment areas and through NEWater and desalination. The Malaysians now have understood our position. They agree that the price of water must be market-competitive. But we have yet to agree on an acceptable basis for a competitive price.

    On 1st July, the Malaysians proposed a price formula. On 2nd July, they told us they are also considering benchmarking the price, among other things, against the China-Hong Kong model and other models. We have explained to the Malaysians why the China-Hong Kong

Column: 591

model is not relevant. But we will study their proposals.

    Singapore's proposal is that the price of any treated water that we may buy from Malaysia after the expiry of the current Agreements should be pegged to an agreed percentage of Singapore's cost of alternative sources of water which is NEWater. Such a formula can withstand the test of time. Singapore is willing to disclose independently audited accounts of our cost of NEWater to work out the price mechanism.

Price Review

    At the recent negotiations, Malaysia informed us that it wanted to invoke the price review clauses of the 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements. The 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements do provide for a review after 25 years. Under the terms of these Agreements, if Malaysia wanted a price review, this should have been undertaken in 1986 and 1987.

    Although it is 15 to 16 years late, we have informed the Malaysians that in the interest of making progress in our talks, Singapore is prepared to consider Malaysia's request to invoke the price review clauses of the 1961 and 1962 Agreements as part of the package.

    We also stressed that any such review must be in accordance with the express provisions of the clauses contained in the 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements. In particular:

    First, the price review must be only on the basis of factors explicitly mentioned in the clauses contained in the 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements. In other words, it must not be a re-negotiation of the existing agreements. The Malaysian side has agreed that any price review must be "consistent with the provisions of the two Agreements."

    Second, as specified in the 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements, the review must cover both the price of the raw water supplied by Malaysia to Singapore and the price of the treated water supplied by

Column: 592

Singapore to Malaysia. The Malaysian side has also agreed to this.

    Third, the price review cannot be retroactive. If we agree to it, it will take effect only from the time that the revision is agreed upon. This is in accordance with the provisions of the price review clauses in the 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements.

    Let me make a final point on the price of water to clear up any possible confusion. In September 2001, there was an in-principle agreement on the price of 60 sen per thousand gallons for future raw water, to be reviewed every five years for inflation, for 100 years after the expiry of the 1962 Agreement in 2061. Although we were not legally obliged to do so, we also offered to pay 45 sen per thousand gallons for raw water currently purchased under the 1961/1962 Agreements as part of an overall package deal that took into account our interests on other issues in the package and the concessions we were making. However, the Malaysians have now advanced completely new and different proposals, taking their earlier offer off the table.

POA, KTM Station/Lands in Singapore and CIQ

    Malaysia informed us that it has decided to relocate its rail CIQ from Tanjong Pagar back to Johor. There was no substantial discussion on this or the joint development of KTM lands in accordance with the POA. I expect this to be taken up at the next meeting.

    Our consistent position is that the POA is a legally binding agreement and its provisions must be observed. Under the POA, the KTM station is to move from Tanjong Pagar to Bukit Timah. However, as part of the package, as I have told the House before, Singapore is prepared to vary the POA to allow the KTM station to shift to Kranji, which the Malaysians had requested, and to include additional railway lands for 60-40% joint development. These are concessions which Singapore will make only as part of the package.

Column: 593



    During our negotiations in July, the Malaysian side assured us that Malaysia is not disputing the legal validity of the POA. Singapore welcomes this assurance. But as part of the package discussions, Malaysia wanted Singapore to agree to include more KTM lands.

Bridge

    We also discussed Malaysia's proposal to replace the Causeway with a road bridge. Malaysia briefed us on its proposal. The Malaysians told us that their preference was for a full bridge, but if there was no agreement, they will proceed with a half bridge on their side of the Causeway.

    We informed the Malaysians that Singapore sees no compelling need to replace the Causeway. But since Malaysia is eager to replace the Causeway with a new bridge, we are prepared to consider jointly building a new bridge as part of the package. Many important details have yet to be worked out, among them the location of the waterway and the clearance height for the passage of vessels and so on. We will continue our discussion on the bridge at the next meeting. We said that we can also go along with Malaysia's proposal to build a railway swing bridge but on this too, there are details to be sorted out.

    There have been many media reports that Malaysia does not consider its proposal for a new bridge to replace the Causeway as part of the package and wants it discussed separately. Let me say that Singapore has made it clear that the bridge will be considered only as part of the package because:

    First, Dr Mahathir's letter of 4th March 2002 clearly set out the proposal for a bridge as one of the issues in the package; so did Prime Minister Goh's reply of 11th April 2002.

    Second, we see no compelling reason to replace the Causeway with a new bridge. Building our side of a new bridge

Column: 594

will cost a lot of money. It makes no sense for us to incur this significant expenditure if the bridge is not part of the package. Singapore can justify this expenditure only if there is agreement on the other issues in the package.

Airspace and CPF

    These issues were not discussed in detail at the last round. We will continue our discussions on airspace and CPF at the next meeting.

Concluding Remarks

    If I may conclude by alluding to what Dr Ong Chit Chung also asked about various press comments. After the 1st to 2nd July negotiations, there has indeed been a flurry of comments based on often inaccurate reports in the Malaysian media. Some have said the ball is in Singapore's court and accused us of being the unreasonable party. This is part of a familiar pattern to make us appear in the wrong with their people.

    We should not be confused by such reports. As I said in this House before on 16th May 2002, such comments constitute a form of psy-war to weaken our morale and soften our position on matters under negotiation. We will calmly and politely state the facts and have them stand the test of time, when truth will out. We should only pay serious attention to what the Malaysian government had said during the actual negotiations and the proposals they had presented on the record.

    Sir, we will continue to approach the talks constructively so that both countries can reach a win-win solution on the package of issues. There is really nothing to be gained by negotiating through the media.

    As I told my colleague, Foreign Minister Syed Hamid, and his delegation, Singapore is making concessions which we are not legally obliged to do. We are not obliged, for example, to agree to their bridge proposal; we are not obliged to

Column: 595

agree to any variation to the POA; and we are also not obliged to allow premature withdrawals of CPF monies by West Malaysian workers. Likewise, we recognise that Malaysia is not legally obliged to supply water after the 1961 and 1962 Agreements expire. Nor is Malaysia legally obliged to restore the use of airspace for the RSAF.

    Therefore, for a deal to be reached, clearly, there has to be give and take. This is why I emphasised to Foreign Minister Syed Hamid that all the issues have to be considered as a package. One cannot look at each issue in isolation and see if one side got more or less. If each side were only to focus on the concessions it is making on one particular item without taking into account the concessions it receives on other aspects of the package, then I think it will be impossible to reach an agreement. Both sides must be prepared to make concessions. Both sides must look at the balance of the total package, and I think this is the only way forward.

    Sir, the issues are complex. I do not think it will be easy to reach an agreement just after one or two meetings. But with political will and a spirit of give and take on both sides, I think it is possible for us to conclude a package. I have informed Foreign Minister Syed Hamid that Singapore would be happy to host the next meeting here. We are now in the process of working out the dates for the Second Ministerial meeting on the package of issues to be held in Singapore.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung (Jurong): Sir, I want to ask the Minister whether he would care to comment on the reported Malaysian proposal to raise the price of water to Malaysian 60 sen per thousand gallons, and then to RM3.00 after 2007, and whether the Minister considers such proposals outrageous and arbitrary.

    Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, I do not think I need to use any adjectives to describe the proposals, but, indeed, these figures were in Dr Mahathir's letter to Senior Minister on 4th March. And they were

Column: 596

also in the first proposal by the Malaysian delegation on 1st July. In other words, Malaysian 60 sen from 2002 to 2006, backdated to 1986 and 1987, and RM3.00 from 2007 to 2011. And they wanted a supplementary agreement to reflect this.

    We could not accept this proposal as, in effect, it would have meant renegotiation and amendment of the existing two Water Agreements. We stated our position that it was not acceptable. Later, the Malaysians informed us that they were no longer seeking a supplementary agreement for that purpose, and instead they would have recourse to the price review clauses under the 1961 and 1962 Agreements, and they would do so consistent with the provisions of the two Agreements.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung: Sir, I wish to ask the Minister whether in points of international law, do the Malaysians have any right to backdate any revisions after so many years when they did not do so earlier. And, whether they have the right to act on it or backdate any revision.

    Prof. Jayakumar: I think the lawyers will have a very interesting time debating this. I think this is a highly arguable point. But the position we have taken is, regardless of the legal ability, as part of the package, in order to advance and make progress in the discussions, we are prepared to look at their request. But it must be part of the package.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung: Sir, the Malaysians have repeatedly talked about the Hong Kong model of water agreement. I wonder whether the Minister would care to comment on the difference between the Hong Kong model and our existing Water Agreements.

    Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, I have said in my main answer that we informed the Malaysians that the Hong Kong model is not relevant. And prior to this, we have made public statements, through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, setting out the position. It is not relevant because, in the case of Hong Kong and China, China bears the infrastructural and operational costs of

Column: 597

supplying raw water to Hong Kong. Hong Kong does not bear any of these costs. So, the analogy is inapplicable. In our case, over the years, it is Singapore which has borne the infrastructural, operational and maintenance costs, such as pipelines, building of dams, and so on. This comes up to be an astronomical figure. So, it is really not comparing apples with apples.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung: Sir, I wish to ask the Minister whether Singapore has proposed any formula for future water negotiations and, likewise, whether the Malaysians made any such proposals on their own.

    Prof. Jayakumar: Can I clarify? Is Dr Ong referring to the price of water for the future, after the expiry of the two Agreements?

    Dr Ong Chit Chung: Yes.

    Prof. Jayakumar: Yes. As I have said, both sides have discussed various proposals. I think both sides now agree that the price for future water under a new agreement to replace the existing two Agreements, upon expiry, must be competitive. But what is the agreed competitive price has yet to be worked out. As I have said just now, we have put forward a proposal. Our proposal is that it must be pegged to the price of alternative sources, which is NEWater. The thrust of our proposal is that we should avoid situations where we have constant disputes over the price of water. Therefore, the proposal that we have tabled would stand the test of time. We will give them all the figures about how NEWater pricing is worked out - the cost and so on. And it makes economic sense for us to agree to a price that must be less than what it costs us to produce NEWater. Otherwise, it does not make any economic sense. So, it has to be an agreed percentage of the cost of producing NEWater. The details will have to be worked out. We have already given them a briefing. So that is the essence, a formula that can stand the test of time

Column: 598

that would not perennially lead to disputes, and it must be competitive.

    The Malaysians have also presented a formula on the first day, which involves factors such as the existing water tariffs, inflation, consumer price index and so on. But Members would have read their public statements that they have said that they would have to rework their figures. On 2nd July, they had revised a proposal where they have said that the price will have to be determined later by agreement. It has to be competitive. But they have said that they want to consider benchmarking with the Hong Kong model or other models. So, we will have to await for their final proposal.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung: Sir, as the Minister is aware that over a period of time, Singapore as well as Malaysia agreed to negotiate on a package of issues. But, recently, Malaysia changed its tack and said it wanted to take the water agreement negotiation outside this package of issues. Will Singapore adhere to our position that we want to negotiate all the issues under a total package of issues?

    Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, that continues to be our position, and that is the position, guideline or direction which the two leaders have given to the negotiating Ministers and officials - that these issues have to be resolved as a package. In fact, if we can go back to the origins of this, it was to be considered as a package because both leaders recognised that these were outstanding issues, and it is best to clear the decks for future relations by resolving these issues as one package.

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND AND RELATED CHANGES


    Resumption of Debate on the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance's Statement [22nd July 2002].

    Question again proposed.
12.59 pm

    Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman (Sembawang): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for giving me the opportunity to participate in the present debate on the proposed changes to the Central Provident Fund. Sir, this is a difficult time for Singaporeans. It is not easy to strike a balance between taking care of the welfare and emotional well being of Singaporeans, and dealing with the hard facts of the economic realities.

    I am pleased to note the comprehensiveness of the measures proposed and announced by DPM Lee yesterday at ensuring that our economy remains competitive and our workers remain employable in a highly gloablised and competitive world.

    Much has been talked about the group of older workers whose employers' CPF contribution has been proposed to remain at 16% when the full restoration of CPF rates takes place. Essentially, they will be experiencing a 4% cut in their salary.

    Sir, I remember when I was doing research on the elderly population, there was the classification of the young old - those aged 60-75, and the old-old - those aged 75 and above. The classification is often times based on their level of economic and social activity. The proposal involving the 50-55 age group seems to

Column: 600

suggest a need to classify another group of "elderly". Perhaps we need to call them the "younger old", or maybe "the not so young", or maybe "the not so old". Whatever we call them, they seem to be a new group of workers that we are concerned about since their age is a determinant in the present debate.

    Sir, the unemployment figures, especially those involving this group of workers, are a cause for concern. The profile of unemployed persons as at June 2001, documented in a Report on Labour Force 2001 by MOM, showed that although workers aged 50 and above make up only 14% of the unemployed, which is proportionate to their proportion in the population, they take the longest time to regain employment. The median duration of unemployment for this group of workers is 14 weeks. They were also found to be more vulnerable to under-employment. It was also reported that job seekers with primary education and below took the longest time to regain employment. Thus, it can be extrapolated that the older workers with lower educational qualifications are the most vulnerable.

    Sir, it is thus understandable to see the measure as a way of reducing the cost of employing older workers. It is based on the assumption that wages of the workers are a key inhibitor for them to regain employment. We first need to understand how the cost of employing these workers has risen. Many speakers in the House have spoken of the seniority wage system, ie, with the seniority comes the practice wisdom that they have acquired all these years. This practice wisdom would then be the value-add that they bring along to their employers.

    Sir, one would hope that the wages of the workers are pegged to their performance or productivity, taking into consideration the practice wisdom and the value-add that they bring along. However, we have heard arguments from the employers that they can find younger workers doing similar jobs done by older workers at a lower price. Is this really so?

Column: 601

If this is so, the issue is thus to look at the wage system, ie, ensuring that the wages are based on performance and not age. Yes, perhaps we have inherited a wage system that has structurally created a stumbling block to our economic system. We need to replace this stumbling block to something that is small, agile and flexible, to ensure that age is not a factor in determining wages, but rather performance.

    Sir, while the proposed changes in the employers' CPF contribution of workers aged 50-55 suggest that the wages of this group of workers are a significant inhibitor to gaining employment, I wonder if it is a valid assumption.

    The Report on Wages in Singapore 2001, published by the Ministry of Manpower, showed that the relationship between age and wages is mediated by the skills level of the workers. It noted, and I quote: "The pace of wage increase with age is more pronounced with the highest skilled workers as their work is generally knowledge intensive." For example, the median gross wage of managers aged 30-35 was $3,930 compared to $5,005 for managers aged 50-55, a 40% difference in favour of the older workers.

    The report, however, continued, and I quote: "The impact of age on wages is less among lower skilled workers. Here, wages generally peaked earlier." In June 2001, the median wage of cleaners, labourers and related workers aged 30-35, for example, was $1,582 compared to $1,298 for workers aged 50-54 years old, a difference of 18% in favour of the younger workers. Another group of lowly skilled workers are the plant and machine operators and assemblers. There is little difference in the median age of the young and older workers in this group with those aged 30-35 earning a median income of $1,878, and those in the 50-54 age group earning $1,810, a very, very small difference.

    Sir, if we evaluate these statistics and the earlier figures on the profile of the

Column: 602

unemployed, with specific reference to the workers in the 50-54 age group, we can infer that perhaps wages are not a significant factor in their ability to seek re-employment. The wages of the older workers with lower skills and education are already lower than the wages of their younger counterparts. Lowering the employers' CPF contribution rate may not be the solution to ensuring their employability. Indeed, it is their skills set and its relevance to the available jobs that are critical. However, Sir, a 4% reduction in salary may mean a lot to this group of workers. I would like to thus echo the call made by Mr Ravindran yesterday for this reduction to be a temporary measure, and for it to be restored when the economic situation improves for this group of workers with their improved skills set.

Addressing the seniority-based wage system

    Our wage system is seniority-based. As my colleague, Matthias Yao, said yesterday, our system is uncommon. I studied wage systems in different countries in the 1980s. So I know our seniority-based wage system is inherently flawed. I knew then that it was uncommon, because other countries used a different principle. My younger colleagues in the unions did not take my word for it. They checked for themselves, as Mr Matthias Yao said yesterday, and confirmed what I found out

Column: 613

almost 20 years ago - that the prevalent system applied elsewhere was one based on job rate.

    Only the Japanese have a seniority-based system similar to ours. From the late 1980s, Japanese companies have had to change it. The Japanese MNCs knew after a period of time that the average wage costs go up under that system and they become uncompetitive. They tried to change, progress was slow. But they have persisted. Let me quote from the article "The Death of Lifetime Employment" in the publication Look Japan, August 2002:

    "The second mainstay of the customary employment system in Japan, seniority-based pay, has also changed. An aging society with fewer children is one of the underlying factors. A salary curve that rises sharply along with employees' age was acceptable in times when there were a greater number of young people. The total personnel costs could be suppressed during times like that, because a greater number of people are paid lower wages. But in an aging society, it has become necessary to revise the seniority-based salary, to keep down total personnel costs. An increasing number of enterprises are raising the proportion of performance-based wages as an incentive for higher performance."



    So, the Japanese realised that and they have been making changes. And, as Mr Matthias Yao said, the right way is the job rate. We have pushed that since 1986. At least, I have pushed for it since 1986. Helping older employees avoid structural unemployment

    There has been another good reason for the reduction in employer's contribution to CPF, ie, to help employees in this age group. They may not see it as such. But retrenchment figures show that a higher proportion of them are laid off when companies restructure. Mr Matthias Yao gave some figures yesterday. We expect restructuring to continue. Ministry of Manpower data shows that workers above 40 years take longer to find re-employment. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon informed Members yesterday of the experience of South West CDC, where the workers looking for jobs, and having a hard time, are those aged 40 and above. Members can get a good idea of the problem, if they spend time in their CDCs helping

Column: 615

those looking for jobs. Age, not educational level, is the key factor, as what the Ministry of Manpower's information tells us. So, is it age discrimination? Or is it the seniority-based wage system?

    A separate 4-year Department of Statistics (DOS) study of 14,000 workers retrenched from October 1997 to September 1998, during the Asian financial crisis, shows that a significant number are now not working - almost 30%. It is a sign that we have structural unemployment. And, unfortunately, we must expect more to come. The DOS findings for those who found re-employment were sobering. Again, age, not education, was the key factor.

Reverse mortgage

    Second, reverse mortgage. In concept, reverse mortgage is a useful device. However, there are risks to the financial institutions offering it. Furthermore, current reverse mortgage proposals are for a fixed term of, say, 10 years.     Elderly HDB flat lessees could also monetise the value of their HDB flat by downgrading either to a rental or to a smaller flat. However, there are currently several impediments for them to do so.

    I also know of a colleague whose widowed mother is living all alone in a 5-room HDB flat and refuses to move out to a smaller flat despite repeated advice from her children.     The second point I wish to raise is the impact of the ERC Sub-Committee's recommendation on home ownership. There has been a chorus of concerns about the over-investment problem and fears that retirement adequacy will be compromised by it.

say, 3 years until HDB flat buyers are more astute with financial planning and discipline and able to do their sums and adapt to the change.

    The ERC's proposal to cut employer's and employee's CPF contribution rate to 16% each for the age group of 50-55 years has, as many of my colleagues before me noted, brought on the loudest chorus of anguished protests among workers.     Sir, I support the bid to improve the overall employability of older workers in the face of persistent structural unemployment. In fact, after Minister Lim Boon Heng's eloquent explanation of the rationale for the CPF cut for this age group, I think it will be very difficult for me to argue otherwise. However, the concerns and arguments of this group are not without merit and should be addressed.

or introducing a monthly variable component in their wage package. Sir, I fervently support these proposals.

    Sir, I therefore applaud the ERC's well-thought out and carefully crafted set of recommendations which attempt to remodel the CPF system and shed the excesses and clutter it had accumulated over the years. The practical phased-in approach of the implementation which allows people and institutions time to appreciate, adapt and accept the change is welcomed.

    Beneath the specifics of the report and the Government's response, lie a gradual but deliberate shrinking of the social safety net. One ultimate intent appears to be that of creating a more entrepreneurial and self-dependent culture, necessary for survival in the new world order. This is indeed a worthwhile goal, but will no doubt engender anxiety and disorientation among many ordinary citizens already reeling from the shock of one of Singapore's worst recessions and painful adjustments in jobs and cost of living.

    In this regard, I would like to again urge the Government to be even-handed in

the implementation of the proposed changes, as well as refine and modify some of the proposals to address the concerns raised. Background

    BCCS was set up in 1967 to implement the currency board system, which Singapore then practised. The features of the currency board system were: first, the exchange rate was fixed between the domestic currency and a specified foreign currency; second, domestic notes and coins were fully convertible at the fixed exchange rate; and third, the domestic currency was fully backed by foreign assets or gold.

    Singapore has progressively evolved away from the system of a fixed exchange rate since the Singapore dollar was floated in 1973. In 1982, convertibility of domestic currency notes and coins into gold and other foreign currencies on demand was repealed. Today, the exchange rate of the Singapore dollar is managed by MAS, against a basket of currencies of our main trading partners, with the objective of keeping inflation low and maintaining the purchasing power of the Singapore dollar.

    The only feature of the currency board system that we have retained is the full backing of currency-in-circulation by external assets. Hence, Singapore no longer operates a currency board system, except for the full backing of currency-in-circulation. This is required under the Currency Act, and has contributed to confidence in the Singapore dollar. This feature will not change after the merger. Currency-in-circulation will continue to be fully backed by external assets all the time.

All dividends, interest, or other revenue from the Currency Fund and the Currency Reserve Fund are paid into a Currency Fund Income Account. All expenses incurred by BCCS are charged to this Currency Fund Income Account.

    With the merger, the Currency Fund and the Currency Reserve Fund will be combined into one fund, which will still be called the Currency Fund. The new Currency Fund will continue to provide at least 100% backing for the currency-in-circulation at all times. Overview of Cheque Truncation System (CTS)

    Let me begin by giving an overview and benefits of the Cheque Truncation System. Singaporeans have written an average of more than 83 million cheques a year over the last 10 years. In 2001, the figure was 92 million. Significant costs are incurred by the banking industry to clear these cheques. Today, after a bank's customer deposits a cheque at his bank, also referred to as the presenting bank, the bank will batch it together with other cheques and transport them to the Automated Clearing House. The Clearing House then sorts the cheques for the respective paying banks to collect, whereupon each paying bank verifies whether the cheques can be paid. If the cheque

    Over the years, the banking industry in Singapore has introduced new technologies to improve this cheque clearing process. An example of this is the magnetic-ink character recognition (MICR) information on cheques that banks have been exchanging to facilitate faster cheque clearing. However, physical cheques are still required by the paying bank because they need to verify information such as dates and signatures on the cheques.

    The Cheque Truncation System, to be launched later this year, leverages on new imaging technology that enables banks to exchange electronic images of cheques. Cheques will be scanned when deposited and their electronic images will be transmitted throughout the entire clearing cycle. The new system will use a private network with public key cryptography to ensure that images are encrypted and transmitted securely between banks. In addition, the system includes a centralised image archive for banks to store and retrieve cheque images. Since a cheque image contains all the necessary information required by a paying bank to determine whether the cheque can be paid, there is no longer an operational necessity for them to have the physical cheque.

This Bill will also recognise the rights of a holder of an Image Return Document, or IRD in short, which is a document that banks will issue instead of returning the original cheque when a cheque is dishonoured. The amendments have been drafted so that under the new process, the respective rights and duties of the various parties to a cheque will be the same as at present.
